title: 111_hr2096
content: The Act titled "Long-Term Care Affordability and Security Act of 2009" addresses the treatment of premiums on qualified long-term care insurance contracts. The Act "Long-Term Care Affordability and Security Act of 2009" amends the Internal Revenue Code to include the payment of premiums for qualified long-term care insurance contracts in cafeteria plans and flexible spending arrangements. It also makes conforming amendments to section 6041 of the Code. The Act "Long-Term Care Affordability and Security Act of 2009" includes provisions for flexible spending arrangements, defining them as benefit programs that reimburse specified expenses within certain limits. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to reflect these changes. Amendments to sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including 3306(b)(18), 3401(a)(22), 4973(g)(1), and 4973(g)(2)(B)(i), are made. Effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2008. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL CONSUMER PROTECTIONS FOR LONG-TERM CARE INSURANCE. Additional protections for long-term care insurance under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require contracts to meet specific model regulation requirements, including guaranteed renewal or noncancellability. The text chunk relates to various sections (6B, 6C, 6D, 6E, 7, 8) of the Act, excluding certain paragraphs, that deal with prohibitions, extension of benefits, continuation of coverage, discontinuance of policies, unintentional lapse, and other related provisions. The curr_chunk summarizes sections 8, 11, 12, 13, and 25 of the Act, excluding specific subsections, which cover disclosure, post-claims underwriting prohibitions, minimum standards, inflation protection requirement, and preexisting conditions prohibition in replacement policies. The curr_chunk outlines requirements related to replacement policies, nonforfeiture benefits, preexisting conditions, and prior hospitalization as per the model Act. The curr_chunk discusses contingent nonforfeiture benefits and defines terms related to long-term care insurance regulations. The curr_chunk discusses the coordination and determination of model regulations and Acts related to insurance, as promulgated by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. It also mentions the excise tax under section 4980C(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. The excise tax under section 4980C(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include requirements of model provisions related to disclosure, application forms, reporting, filing, and standards for marketing. Additionally, certain sections such as 24, 27, 31, and 32 are also included in the amendments. The model Act must meet requirements such as the right to return, outline of coverage, certificates under group plans, policy summary, monthly reports on accelerated death benefits, incontestability period, and producer standards. The amendments made by this section, including producer training requirements, shall apply to policies issued more than 1 year after the enactment of this Act.
